lesson.name: Unit 4: Part 3: Alternative and Formative Learner Assessment

page.title: Benefits of Alternative Assessments
page.contents:
“Formative assessment means asking the right questions at the right time.”

Peter deWitt, Education Week

Listen to audio

ELL_Mod3_4160.mp3

Audio Transcript


All assessments have both benefits and advantages. Which one of these benefits could persuade you to try some of the alternative assessments discussed in this unit? What other benefits do you see?

Alternative assessments can be summative or formative:

1. Summative assessments capture the knowledge and competencies at the end of a course. These assessments can be used to document what has been learned and can signal if a student is ready to transition into work or into a training program.

2. Formative Assessments provide feedback to teachers and students. These assessments can guide instruction and improve the teaching–learning process.

Alternative assessments can

  • help students self-assess their knowledge and skills;

  • capture dispositions, including student perceptions of their own abilities to learn and persist; and

  • help document a more complex set of skills, including self-management, problem solving, and the ability to work in teams.

page.title: Bright Ideas to Try
page.contents:
1. Have students identify their passions. Offer some topics to explore on the Internet and then see where students’ interests take them. Tie this information to discussion on possible careers.

  2. Invite students to use signals to indicate if they have understood something completely (concept, directions, terminology) , are still a bit fuzzy, or are very confused. Reteach as necessary.

  3. Observe students during group work and take notes on who speaks up and who leads the group. Use this information to identify possible student mentors.

  4. Ask students to draw a career pathway, using a storyboard technique. Have students draw question marks for a pathway step that is not clear to them.

  5. Institute project-based learning (PBL) to teach complex skills important in modern workplaces. Create opportunities for students to plan, do research, and present their information. Consider having students create exhibits similar to those used in science fairs.

page.title: Six Critical Assessment Questions for ELL Career Pathways
page.contents:
1. How can I find out what technical materials students might be able to read and understand?

  2. How can I tell whether students are familiar with technical vocabulary?

  3. How can I demonstrate to my students that they are making progress and increasing their competence in specific domains?

  4. How can I document that students are developing career readiness skills?

  5. How can I find out whether students are learning what I teach?

  6. How can my program determine if students are ready to participate in a program that links English acquisition with skills training?

In answering these questions, here are some tools you might consider.

page.title: Case in Point: Matching Student Needs with Program Goals
page.contents:
Listen to audio

ELL_Mod3_4170.mp3

Audio Transcript


Alternative assessments can be combined into a holistic assessment that offers detailed information about a student’s background and his or her readiness to participate in an ambitious program that requires a great deal of commitment. Holistic assessments happen at intake and seek to capture skills, as well as needs.

The Alamo Colleges in San Antonio, Texas, offer such as holistic assessment in their Integrated Basic Education and Skills Training (I-BEST) course. After an initial assessment, students attend a short-term, industry-specific career exploration and enhancement course. The course asks students about the level of commitment they are able to make and helps them make informed decisions about the training course that will best meet their needs. The assessment not only assesses students’ level of English but asks about their ability to read and write in Spanish. Students discuss the family support they need and the social service support they currently receive.

Students also explore career interests and goals and report on their past education and work experience.

In the Alamo orientation course, holistic assessment is combined with career exploration, so that students can make a full commitment to a set of courses that integrate basic skills, including English acquisition, into the teaching of technical skills.

Take a look at the attached Alamo I-BEST Intake Form. Which of these categories does your program assess? Which questions could you add to your assessment? What are your thoughts regarding a weeklong student orientation, intake, and assessment session? Do you think such a session might be worthwhile?

For thoughts on developing the course, see the attached white paper developed by the Alamo Colleges.

The Integrated Basic Education and Skills Training (I-BEST) program at the Alamo Colleges, in San Antonio, Texas, has developed a holistic assessment that allows both learners and staff to assess whether the college programs match what students need.

The weeklong orientation and assessment sessions cover the following:

  • Quantitative and qualitative assessments of education and work experience

  • Career interests and goals

  • Support needs

  • English proficiency and Spanish literacy

Alamo Colleges. Alamo I-BEST RAPID form A (Reliable Assessment of Proficiency for Individual Development), Version 3/18/13. Copyright 2013 by Anson Green. American Institutes for Research used with permission from Anson Green.

page.title: Reflection Questions
page.contents:
Holistic assessments allow you to look beyond test scores and gain a sense of what a student’s talents and dreams might be—for life, as well as for a career. These assessments also offer insights into a student’s readiness to take on an intensive program or commit to a particular job.

Think about the questions you might ask your students and record your answers in your notes.

For a look at the summary form that the Alamo Colleges are using.

For more information on the Alamo I-BEST, read the attached white paper.

1. You want to learn more about a student’s language experience and language use. What questions could you ask?

2. You are an advisor in a contextualization program. Many of the students lead challenging lives, and you are worried about their ability to persist in a training program. What questions would you ask? What support could you provide or suggest?

3. Your students don’t speak much English, but you suspect they have had experience working as entrepreneurs in the informal economy in the United States. What questions would you ask? What questions wouldn’t you ask?

page.title: Students Self-Assess Ability to Read Technical Information
page.contents:
Listen to audio

ELL_Mod3_4180.mp3

Audio transcript


Many ELL teachers have used self-assessments, including reflection notes on portfolios and can-do lists. One of the most worthwhile assessments for career pathways includes the use of authentic materials and technical textbooks. Known as a reading demonstration, this assessment invites students to leaf through industry-related materials and (peruse) a series of textbooks written at different levels. Students then discuss with one another and with the teacher which materials they found intriguing and would like to know more about, and which textbooks they felt competent enough to tackle.

You can use this kind of assessment as part of a one-on-one assessment or work with a small group after you give individual students a chance to look over the materials and form their responses.

This sort of self-assessment gives you information about students’ interest levels, as well as about their proficiency in handling different levels of text complexity.

Asking student to review textbooks and assess their ability to read them assesses both interest and competence

Bright Idea:  

  1. Bring in materials from the occupational field written at different levels. Include college and high school textbooks, brochures advertising classes, trade publications, catalogues, and magazines written for interested lay persons.

  2. Ask students to choose some texts they can read easily and invite them to read them aloud with you. Ask one or more easy comprehension questions.

  3. Depending on how fluently the student reads, select either an easier or a more challenging text and invite the student to try to read it.   

  4. Ask how interesting the student finds the text (very, not very). Record responses.

page.title: Questions
page.contents:
Asking learners to show you what they are interested in reading and what they can read provides you with valuable information. Think about the potential of this kind of self-assessment for your class .

1. Does the “show me what you can understand” process seem workable to you? Why or why not?

2. Think of a field your students might be interested in. Where would you go to collect authentic materials? Share your ideas with your Community of Practice, or with your colleagues on the LINCS discussion forum. 

3. You have a large class. How could you adapt this assessment to pair or small-group work?
